questions.question_text: A technician needs to connect several computers in close proximity to control manufacturing equipment in a factory. The medium to connect the computers must be cost effective and suitable for short distances. Which of the following mediums should the technician use?

discussion.content: Process of the elimination: A = telephone connector with a ethernet cable WRONG, B= Fiber connector with ethernet cable WRONG C= coaxial cable connector with a type of fire proof cable WRONG, D was the most logical answer left

C is correct, Computers do not have BNC Connectors. They do/can have DB9 (Serial) connectors and that can also be used to control devices or Machines here is a real life example of the cord they are referring to https://www.amazon.com/Plenum-White-Jacket-Serial-Cable/dp/B0077RFTUA

"The RG59 is used for cable TV. RG-59 uses a copper plated steel central conductor and is designed to have 75 ohms of resistance. Because of that we can not use this type of cable for computer networks."

Should be C, DB9 is at least used in PCs, albeit old ones. Here's an article detailing how to connect 2 PCs through serial connection: https://www.conniq.com/WinXPNetworking_DCC_serial_parallel.htm
The final question! If you made it this far give this a thumbs up and good luck!
I’m imagining that i am a network technician going to a company to provide networking services for a client who can’t access the wireless network, but the solution is to turn on the wireless

questions.question_text: A network technician is troubleshooting a laptop that does not have wireless connectivity. The technician determines the wireless network is functioning as expected. The laptop does not show any SSIDs or allow the technician to modify network settings. Which of the following should the technician check FIRST?

choices.A: Check for overcapacity of the network.
choices.B: Ensure wireless is enabled on the laptop.
choices.C: Confirm the power levels of the WAP.

discussion.content: Surely D. EUI-64?

Selected Answer: D
Who answers these questions? ...
eui64 no doubt
Just enforcing what many others are saying...APIPA is for IPv4, not IPv6. The correct answer is D. "d0ggyl0v3r" and "b0ugi3" explanations are spot-on.
Extended Unique Identifier 64 (EUI-64) is the process that allows a host to assign itself a unique IPv6 address

Selected Answer: A
Automatic Private IP Addressing (APIPA) is a feature in operating systems (such as Windows) that enables computers to automatically self-configure an IP address and subnet mask when their DHCP server isn't reachable

Selected Answer: D
D is the correct answer. IPv4 is APIPA so the process of elimination means EUI-64.
A is the wrong answer. D is correct.
D is the correct answer
No idea what EUI-64 was but sure enough it is a Net+ objective. I would say D.

IPv6 does NOT use APIPA, this applies only to IPv4.

The answer is EUI-64. Explanation:
EUI-64 (Extended Unique Identifier) is a method we can use to automatically configure IPv6 host addresses. An IPv6 device will use the MAC address of its interface to generate a unique 64-bit interface ID. However, a MAC address is 48 bit and the interface ID is 64 bit.
what is the correct answer for this?

Many people get confused about IPv6 link-local addresses when they are first learning about IPv6 because there isn’t really any IPv4 equivalent of this type of IPv6 address. However, the only thing that comes close to IPv6 link-local addresses is the IPv4 Automatic Private IP Addressing (APIPA) method. When a host fails to obtain an IPv4 address with DHCP, it resigns itself to its fate of being incommunicado, and assigns its interface an APIPA address. You have surely witnessed (likely in a moment of exasperated troubleshooting!) a host with an IPv4 address in the 169.254.0.0/16 range (see RFC 3927). Like IPv6 link-local addresses, these APIPA addresses are usable addresses for unicast communications within a single broadcast domain on the LAN.
EUI-64

this is what google says, and sounds like the best answer... 
EUI-64 (Extended Unique Identifier) is a method we can use to automatically configure IPv6 host addresses. An IPv6 device will use the MAC address of its interface to generate a unique 64-bit interface ID.
Yeaaaaaaahhh this is very wrong. APIPA only applies to IPv4. EUI-64 is the IPv6 equivalent of APIPA, assigning a link-local address.
EUI-64 is similar to DHCP, but for IPv6. Can anyone verify that D is correct?

questions.question_text: A network technician is implementing a new IPv6 addressing scheme at a local office. This is a large office, and the network manager would like a solution that saves time and allows for automatic addressing of nodes. Which of the following would BEST accomplish this?

A network administrator notices that network utilization is extremely high around midnight and wonders if this is normal or if there might be a security issue. Which of the following types of documentation should the administrator consult FIRST?

discussion.content: Baseline was my first guess, but after rereading the question, it's formatted in a way that almost indicates the admin knows his baseline based off noticing the network utilization being higher than normal. Because he tells himself this, you'd assume he knows his baseline and the next step is to check change management documentation. That's my best explanation.

comments.content: "or if there might be a security issue" this is another indicator change management is the answer.
"and wonders if this is normal" doesn't imply to me that he knows his baseline.

discussion.content: Definitely C. Talked to prof too

comments.content: Who is this all knowing prof you speak of? With how these tests are worded, sometimes profs are wrong. Unless that prof is Professor Messer of course.

discussion.content: Logical steps would be to check if something has changed (Change Management Documentation), then check the baseline.
"if this is normal or if there might be a security issue" ( i choose C)
Y'all are really overthinking this one
I think it should be C. 'he wonders if this is normal'. that means he's not sure whether this is how it should be or not. Just my thoughts.

Answer is vaguely in the question... Somewhere somehow the network admin determined the utilization is not normal at midnight(hint)... Therefore he has an idea what the baseline is in order for him to know it is not normal... So now he knows it is not normal he says "Let me see if anything has changed" (Change management doc)... (A)
If this is the first and only time he sees this then the answer is A. If he notices this high utilization more than once then the answer is C.
The question is saying that Network Utilization is high everyday past midnight. It is not suggesting a change was done. Can't be A, therefore it's C.

comments.content: it doesn't say everyday past midnight. This is why the answer is A and not C.

discussion.content: "He wonders if this is normal." That sounds like he needs to check the baseline.
The network performance baseline has already known because It says the usage is high. So, we need to find out if there is a recent change.

Change mgmt does not apply here. Perhaps the question intended to indicate that the Tech should look for changes within the network as a first step. (C) Baseline would do this. Now if there is a change from baseline then perhaps looking at Change MGMT documentation would be in order.

A is correct, Network Troubleshooting Methodology.
1. Identify the problem:
• Gather information.
•Duplicate the problem, if possible.
•Question users.
•Identify symptoms.
•Determine if anything has changed. (review change management documents) 
•Approach multiple problems individually.
IT IS C
Why it can't C?

questions.question_text: A network technician needs to dedicate a range of addresses in DHCP for statically assigned servers and network devices. Which of the following should be configured to BEST accomplish this?

discussion.content:
From the Net+ Guide Book "Another common concern in DHCP configurations is to exclude IP addresses from
the scope of addressed you make available. We call these IP exclusions. You might do
this for several servers you have in your organization that required configurations with
a static IP address in the scope of your overall IP address space. IP exclusions are simple to configure and ensure that an IP address conflict does not result in your subnet."
I believe A is the correct answer
exclusions are unusable and therefore not the answer here...going static addressing

comments.content: but it prevents the IP range from being assigned automatically, but you can still assign these addresses to people

discussion.content: Why not a subnet?

An exclusion is a range of addresses that are not included in a scope. The exclusion range falls within the range of the scope's starting and ending addresses. In effect, an exclusion range lets you punch a hole in a scope. The IP addresses that fall within the hole won't be assigned.
Someone please explain
